root.name: Clannad
root.description: OverviewClannad is a visual novel developed by Key and published by Visual Art's for the Windows PC in Japan on April 28, 2004. Unlike Key's previous works Kanon and Air, Clannad was developed as an all-ages title. It proved to be a huge success and it was the best-selling PC game in Japan at the time of its release. Clannad was later ported to the PlayStation 2 by Interchannel, Ltd.. A fully voiced edition was later released on February 29, 2008 and it was ported to the PlayStation Portable, XBox 360, and PlayStation 3 by Prototype.Key later produced an adult spin-off title called Tomoyo After: It's a Wonderful Life for the PC on November 25, 2005 which expands on the story of one of the heroines, Tomoyo Sakagami.Clannad was never released outside of Japan, but an unofficial English translation patch was initiated and released by Baka-Tsuki (hosted here) which is mostly workable. The project was then taken over by Doki Fansubs on June 7, 2012.PlotThe game is divided into two portions: the School Life arc and the After Story arc.School LifeTomoya Okazaki is a final year high-school student resentful of his life. His mother passed away from a car accident when he was younger, causing his father to resort to alcohol and gambling. This resulted in fights between the two until Tomoya's shoulder was injured in a fight, ending his basketball career. Since then, Tomoya has had a distant relationship with his father, causing him to become a delinquent over time. While on a walk to school, he meets a strange girl named Nagisa Furukawa who is a year older, but is repeating due to illness. Due to this, she is often alone as most of her friends have moved on. The two begin hanging out and slowly, as time goes by, Tomoya finds his life shifting in a new direction.After StoryThe After Story arc continues from where the Nagisa plot-line left off. After graduating from high school, Tomoya and Nagisa's relationship begins to enter a level of intimacy unlike before. Through his relationship with Nagisa, and his various encounters, Tomoya begins to understand the meaning and importance of family. However, as Tomoya and Nagisa begin their own family together, they are faced with many hardships and challenges along the way.Main CharactersTomoya Okazaki: He is the main protagonist in Clannad. Currently enrolled in high school, Tomoya has a reputation as a delinquent. He is a very direct person when speaking to others, never holding back when he has something to say much to the annoyance of some characters. Throughout the game however, he's proven to be quite reliable in a pinch and willing to help out his friends to a startling degree, often going to extreme lengths to support them in whatever situation demands it.Nagisa Furukawa: She is the main female lead in Clannad. Nagisa is a very shy character who doesn't think much of herself. Due to those two qualities and her extreme lack of self-confidence, she's often unable to confront people when a problem arises or properly speak her mind. Due to a sickness, she's forced to repeat her last year of high school which is where she encounters Tomoya.Ryou Fujibayashi: Ryou is first introduced as Tomoya's classmate. Twin sister of Kyou, Ryou is deeply invested into psychic powers, most prominently in using cards which she carries around in her bag. Extremely shy even though she holds the position of class president, Ryou is not good at confronting or socializing with most people.Kyou Fujibayashi: Twin sister of Ryou and also a class president, Kyou is a fierce and aggressive girl who won't hesitate to throw a dictionary at someone when she thinks that person is harassing her sister. Despite her initially fierce personality, she also has a more sociable side and is a very good cook.Fuko Ibuki: Fuko is a short girl who avoids relationships with people, up until Tomoya finds her alone in a classroom carving wooden starfish. She has an undying love for star-shaped objects and especially starfish and upon encountering said objects, will mostly likely go into a trance while thinking about them.Tomoyo Sakagami: Introduced as a transfer student, Tomoyo quickly makes a reputation for herself as somewhat of a perfect girl, strong in athletics, beauty, and studies. Although she is perfect in all these ways, she sometimes shows a naive side.Kotomi Ichinose: The only child of two brilliant scholars, Kotomi is a genius even amongst all of Japan, ranked in the top 10 of the Japan in every subject. Unfortunately, due to only studying all the time since she was a child, she has terrible social skills and cannot talk to or approach anyone and often becomes completely deaf of the outside world when reading a book.Ushio Okazaki: Tomoya and Nagisa's daughter. She appears prominently in the After Story arc. Ushio resembles her mother, and seems to like the Great Dango Family mascots as well.Naoyuki Okazaki: Tomoya's father. His wife died when Tomoya was young, thus leaving only himself to raise Tomoya. After the accident, Naoyuki turned to alcohol and smoking, and had frequent fights with his son. One day, while arguing with his son, he slammed Tomoya against the wall, injuring Tomoya's right shoulder. Ever since then, Naoyuki has treated Tomoya more kindly, but like a stranger rather than family.Akio Furukawa: Nagisa's father and the husband of Sanae Furukawa. He is shown to be an avid smoker, and although he often talks and plays rough, he is kind and sympathetic. His child-like side makes it easy for kids and adults alike to befriend him. He runs the Furukawa Bakery with his wife Sanae.Sanae Furukawa: Nagisa's mother. Normally she's quite childish, but when needed she can be very strong-willed and dependable. She runs the Furukawa Bakery with her husband Akio. She often tries out strange concepts to make breads that are anything but edible, and almost never get sold. Outside of the bakery, she tutors children.Youhei Sunohara: Tomoya's friend and fellow delinquent. He entered the school on an athletic recommendation in soccer/football, but was kicked out of the club after a fight against older members who harassed younger players. Since then, he became a lazy delinquent. He has a sister named Mei who he was very protective of when they were younger, but to her dismay this aspect of him became repressed after he quit soccer. One of the story paths involves him repairing his relationship with his sister.GameplayLike many visual novels, the gameplay revolves around making moral decisions and dialogue choices that impact the non-linear branching narrative. The game has various different plot-lines the player could follow based on their choices, leading to a variety of different alternate endings.The School Life arc has five major plot-lines as well as several additional smaller scenarios, with over a dozen possible endings. When the player completes a character's scenario, he or she receives an orb of light. When eight of these lights are obtained, the game's second story arc, After Story, is made available. The After Story arc continues from where the Nagisa plot-line left off and has several possible alternate endings of its own.Originally, the lights were meant to be items that players could use in the game, but since this increased the game's complexity, and detracted from the storyline, the function of the lights was simplified and made less intrusive.On Yukine's story path, the player can take part in a storage room spell where Tomoya will be locked up in the sports equipment storage room with a particular character. The character who will be involved will depend on the choices made up until that point.On Fuko's story path, the player is given the choice to play pranks on her. There are 4 available types of pranks and they can be used twice each. The chance to use them is presented during specific parts of the story path, with certain pranks giving different results depending on the occasion. Certain occasions will not allow certain pranks to be used.ConceptsTime and DateTime, day, and date is an important feature in Key's works. Clannad provides a day and date display which can be toggled via the options menu. The story line follows a predetermined schedule, incorporating half school days on Saturday, school holidays and events.The first day of school is on April 14, 2003. The School Founder's Day is on May 11.School UniformsThe school uniforms uses different color badges which is pinned to the shirt pocket to signify the students' schooling year. First years wear green, second years wear red, and third years wear blue.The Big Dango FamilyNagisa and the Big Dango FamilyA recurring theme in Clannad. Dango translates to rice dumpling.The Big Dango Family, also known as The Great Dango Family (dango daikazoku in Japanese) is a fictional group mascot which comprises of a big happy family of 100 dangos of many colors. They represent strong familial relationship. In Clannad, Nagisa and her family loves the Big Dango Family.The Big Dango Family has a theme song, which is also the theme song for Nagisa and Clannad. The song is sung by Nagisa, then later by Ushio as well.Light OrbsObtaining a light orbLight orbs represent a person's happiness. It can be consumed to make a wish.An orb is obtain when Tomoya successfully completes a character's story path. There are a total of 8 orbs that must be obtained during the School Life arc in order to unlock the After Story arc.The story paths that provide light orbs on the School Life arc are Misae, Yukine, Tomoyo, Kotomi, Kyou, Kappei, the Sunohara Siblings, and Koumura. Fuko's story path will consume a light orb.The choices made in Nagisa's story path will influence the After Story arc. The After Story arc contains another 6 light orbs, which are from Sanae, Akio, Yusuke, Naoyuki, Fuko, and Kouko. This totals to 13 which is needed to unlock the True Ending.Illusionary WorldTomoya experiences a sequential dream which takes place in the Illusionary World. The Illusionary World is a vast desolate land with only a single remaining living girl. The name of the girl is never stated. She has the ability to create dolls out of junk that lies scattered across the landscape. Tomoya's dream is seen through the eyes of one of the dolls that she had created. He is unable to talk in the dream, and instead communicates with the girl through gestures.ReceptionThe Clannad visual novel has been highly acclaimed. In the October 2007 issue of Dengeki G's Magazine, poll results of the 50 best "bishoujo games" were released. Out of 249 titles, Clannad ranked first at 114 votes; in comparison, the second place title, Fate/stay night, received 78 votes. In 2008, Clannad was voted No. 2 in the Dengeki poll of most tear-inducing video games of all time. In 2011, Clannad was voted No. 4 in Famitsu's poll of most tear-inducing video games of all time.An article published by the John Hopkins University proclaimed Clannad as the visual novel's "magnum opus" for fully realizing the potential of the visual novel medium, comparing its impact to that of Ulysses for novels, Citizen Kane for cinema, and Watchmen for comic books. The same article also stated that Clannad "proved more emotionally powerful than works like Titanic, for successfully moving the reader without the forcing a reaction upon them."AdaptationsThere have been two anime adaptations. The first was a 2007 anime film by Toei Animation. The second, more acclaimed, adaptation was an anime television series by Kyo-Ani from 2007 to 2009. The series was divided, much like the game, into two seasons, the first called just Clannad and the second called Clannad After Story; it was After Story in particular that received the most acclaim.The anime series adaptation has been widely acclaimed, with Clannad After Story in particular being one of the highest user-rated anime of all time at sites like Anime News Network and MyAnimeList. It has also received highly positive reviews from various critics, including DVD Talk, THEM Anime Reviews, and Anime News Network.Clannad has also been adapted into a variety of other media, including novels, manga comics, and audio dramas.
